qas.question: Whose ideas became increasingly radical during his imprisonment?
What organization was led by Hasan al-Hudaybi?
What movements pursued a more radical direction?
When had the Brotherhood renounced violence as a means of achieving its goals?
Whose ideas did not become increasingly radical during his imprisonment?
What organization was defeated by Hasan al-Hudaybi?
What movements did not pursue a more radical direction?
When did the Brotherhood support violence as a means of achieving its goals?

context: While <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>Qutb<a0_1/>'s<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_0/> ideas became increasingly radical during his imprisonment prior to his execution in <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>1966<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, the leadership of <a2_0><a2_1><b7_0>the <a2_2>Brotherhood<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, led by Hasan al-Hudaybi, remained moderate and interested in political negotiation and activism. <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>Fringe<a3_2/> or splinter<b8_0/><a3_0/> movements<a3_1/> inspired by the final writings of Qutb in the mid-1960s (particularly the manifesto Milestones, a.k.a. Ma'alim fi-l-Tariq) did, however, develop and they pursued a more radical direction. <a4_0>By <a4_1>the <a4_2><b9_0>1970s<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, the Brotherhood had renounced violence as a means of achieving its goals.
